locations.description:
An attack that misses by 1 hits the torso instead. Only
impaling (imp), piercing (pi-, pi, pi+, pi++), and
tight-beam burning (burn) attacks can target the eye – and
only from the front or sides. Injury over HP÷10 blinds the
eye. Otherwise, treat as skull, but without the extra DR!

An attack that misses by 1 hits the torso instead. Wounding
modifier is x4. Knockdown rolls are at -10. Critical hits
use the Critical Head Blow Table (B556). Exception: These
special effects do not apply to toxic (tox) damage.

An attack that misses by 1 hits the torso instead. Jaw,
cheeks, nose, ears, etc. If the target has an open-faced
helmet, ignore its DR. Knockdown rolls are at -5. Critical
hits use the Critical Head Blow Table (B556). Corrosion
(cor) damage gets a x1½ wounding modifier, and if it
inflicts a major wound, it also blinds one eye (both eyes on
damage over full HP). Random attacks from behind hit the
skull instead.

Reduce the wounding multiplier of large piercing (pi+), huge
piercing (pi++), and impaling (imp) damage to x1. Any major
wound (loss of over ½ HP from one blow) cripples the limb.
Damage beyond that threshold is lost.

Reduce the wounding multiplier of large piercing (pi+), huge
piercing (pi++), and impaling (imp) damage to x1. Any major
wound (loss of over ½ HP from one blow) cripples the limb.
Damage beyond that threshold is lost. If holding a shield,
double the penalty to hit: -4 for shield arm instead of -2.

An attack that misses by 1 hits the torso instead. Human
males and the males of similar species suffer double shock
from crushing (cr) damage, and get -5 to knockdown rolls.
Otherwise, treat as a torso hit.

Reduce the wounding multiplier of large piercing (pi+), huge
piercing (pi++), and impaling (imp) damage to x1. Any major
wound (loss of over ½ HP from one blow) cripples the limb.
Damage beyond that threshold is lost. If holding a shield,
double the penalty to hit: -4 for shield arm instead of -2.

Reduce the wounding multiplier of large piercing (pi+), huge
piercing (pi++), and impaling (imp) damage to x1. Any major
wound (loss of over ½ HP from one blow) cripples the limb.
Damage beyond that threshold is lost.

If holding a shield, double the penalty to hit: -8 for
shield hand instead of -4. Reduce the wounding multiplier of
large piercing (pi+), huge piercing (pi++), and impaling
(imp) damage to x1. Any major wound (loss of over ⅓ HP
from one blow) cripples the extremity. Damage beyond that
threshold is lost.

Reduce the wounding multiplier of large piercing (pi+), huge
piercing (pi++), and impaling (imp) damage to x1. Any major
wound (loss of over ⅓ HP from one blow) cripples the
extremity. Damage beyond that threshold is lost.

An attack that misses by 1 hits the torso instead. Neck and
throat. Increase the wounding multiplier of crushing (cr)
and corrosion (cor) attacks to x1½, and that of cutting
(cut) damage to x2. At the GM’s option, anyone killed by a
cutting (cut) blow to the neck is decapitated!

An attack that misses by 1 hits the torso instead. Heart,
lungs, kidneys, etc. Increase the wounding modifier for an
impaling (imp) or any piercing (pi-, pi, pi+, pi++) attack
to x3. Increase the wounding modifier for a tight-beam
burning (burn) attack to x2. Other attacks cannot target the
vitals.

children.name: Curious
children.notes: Make a self-control roll when presented with an interesting item or situation

children.name: Charitable
children.notes: Make a self-control roll in any situation where you could render aid or are specifically asked for help, but should resist the urge

children.name: Code of Honor (Gentleman's)
children.notes: Never break your word. Never ignore an insult to yourself, a lady, or your flag; insults may only be wiped out by an apology or a duel (not necessarily to the death!). Never take advantage of an opponent in any way; weapons and circumstances must be equal (except in open war). This only applies between gentlemen.

children.name: Impulsiveness
children.notes: Make a self-control roll whenever it would be wise to wait and ponder. If you fail, you must act

children.name: Overconfidence
children.notes: You must make a self-control roll any time the GM feels you show an unreasonable degree of caution. If you fail, you must go ahead as though you were able to handle the situation!

Saddle Training. A horse can be trained to work with arider, providing +1 to Riding (Horse), for +0.5 CF to cost;+2 is +3 CF. For an additional +1 CF, the horse is trained torespond to knee pressure, allowing use of both arms whileretaining control of the mount
Thoroughbred. Most horses have Enhanced Move (Monsters, p. 10), calculated as a multiple of Move: ×1.5 is free,×2 is +4 CF, and ×2.5 is +24 CF. A top-end racehorse mightbe ST 22 with Move 8/20.
Leap and Fight. Horses can be trained specifically in Brawling and Jumping. Gett ing a skill at DX+1 is +1 CF tocost; DX+2 is +3 CF.

children.text:
O Legado do Jovem Richard de Clare, o Hedge Knight

No coração da Inglaterra medieval, a família de Richard de Clare, o 3º Conde de Hertford, era conhecida por sua riqueza e poder. Possuindo vastas terras na Inglaterra, Gales e Kent, eles eram nobres respeitados e temidos em igual medida. No entanto, o jovem Richard de Clare, Quarto filho do conde, tinha sonhos que divergiam do destino tradicional de sua linhagem.

O jovem Richard, nomeado em homenagem ao pai, cresceu entre as muralhas imponentes do Castelo de Clare, cercado por luxo e privilégios. No entanto, desde tenra idade, ele nutriu uma fascinação por histórias de cavaleiros errantes e a vida de liberdade que eles levavam. Enquanto os corredores do castelo ecoavam com intrigas políticas e obrigações feudais, o jovem Richard sonhava com aventuras e a simplicidade da estrada.

Conforme os anos passavam, Richard de Clare, o jovem, decidiu seguir seu próprio caminho. Ele abraçou a vida de um Hedge Knight, um cavaleiro errante que percorria os reinos em busca de aventuras, justiça e um senso pessoal de honra.

Equipado com uma armadura simples e sua espada de família, ele partiu em sua jornada solitária. Em sua busca por justiça, ele enfrentou bandidos, defendeu aldeias indefesas e protegeu os oprimidos. Ele conheceu Nobles e plebeus, compartilhando histórias e lições com pessoas de todas as esferas da vida.

 Ele não carregava títulos ou riquezas, mas sua honra e coragem eram conhecidas. Ele personificou a ideia de que a verdadeira nobreza estava no coração e nas ações, não apenas nos títulos de nobreza.

A história de Richard de Clare, O jovem, lembrava a todos que o verdadeiro valor de um homem não estava no que ele possuía, mas no que ele fazia com o poder que tinha, e que o chamado para a aventura e a busca da justiça poderiam inspirar a nobreza em qualquer alma corajosa, independentemente de seu nome de nascimento.

Familia
Gilbert de Clare (ca. 1180 – 25 de outubro de 1230), 4.º Conde de Hertford e 5.º Conde de Gloucester , (ou 1.º Conde de Gloucester de nova criação). Casado em 1217 com Isabel Marechal .
Maud de Clare (ca. 1184–1213), casou -se em 1206, [ carece de fontes ] Sir William de Braose, filho de William de Braose e Maud de St.

Sir William Marshal
